title: Jeffrey T.K.V. Koh | Web Directory | Singapore Institute of Technology

meta.description: Jeffrey, a transdisciplinary experiential designer, has spent most of his life in Toronto, Canada but has had the opportunity to live, work, and study in numerous global cities such as Sydney, Zurich, London, Rotterdam, Berlin, Seoul, Singapore, and Tokyo. With his diverse background and expertise, Jeffrey has worked on a range of projects including catwalk and fashion show designs for PRADA, advertising and gallery curation for KesselsKramer, and architecture and exhibition design for the Office for Metropolitan Architecture / Rem Koolhaas. As a practising artist, Jeffrey has showcased his work in prestigious venues such as the Barbican and Southbank Centre in London, the Singapore Design Festival, and in galleries located in Munster, Berlin, Vienna, Crete, Tokyo, among other world-class venues. Jeffrey has studied Semiotics and Fashion Photography and obtained his BFA in Monumental Kunst from the Aki Academy of Art and Design (ArtEZ) in Enschede, the Netherlands, as well as an MA in Creative Practice for Narrative Environments from Central Saint Martins College of Art & Design in London, United Kingdom. He also earned a d.MBA in business design in 2021. Moreover, Jeffrey's research interests have focused on various topics related to HCI, HRI, interactivity, and transdisciplinary experimental creative practice. He obtained his PhD from the National University of Singapore and was a visiting research scholar at Keio University in Japan. Previously, Jeffrey served as the UX Lead at the National Gallery Singapore, a Peer of the Australia Council for the Arts, a faculty Lecturer at UNSW, Vice President of Transmedia at Villains, and a Partner at Chemistry. He currently serves as an Advisory Board Member at Chemistry, as well as Ngee Ann Polytechnic's School of Design, is a founding member of the World Economic Forum Singapore Chapter, and is an Associate Professor at SIT, focusing on regenerative design and the circular economy.

text_lines: This question is for testing whether or not you are a human visitor and to prevent automated spam submissions.
Head, Design Factory @ Singapore Institute of Technology (DF@SIT)
PhD Integrative Sciences & Engineering, National University of Singapore, Singapore

Jeffrey, a transdisciplinary experiential designer, has spent most of his life in Toronto, Canada but has had the opportunity to live, work, and study in numerous global cities such as Sydney, Zurich, London, Rotterdam, Berlin, Seoul, Singapore, and Tokyo.

With his diverse background and expertise, Jeffrey has worked on a range of projects including catwalk and fashion show designs for PRADA, advertising and gallery curation for KesselsKramer, and architecture and exhibition design for the Office for Metropolitan Architecture / Rem Koolhaas.

As a practising artist, Jeffrey has showcased his work in prestigious venues such as the Barbican and Southbank Centre in London, the Singapore Design Festival, and in galleries located in Munster, Berlin, Vienna, Crete, Tokyo, among other world-class venues.

Jeffrey has studied Semiotics and Fashion Photography and obtained his BFA in Monumental Kunst from the Aki Academy of Art and Design (ArtEZ) in Enschede, the Netherlands, as well as an MA in Creative Practice for Narrative Environments from Central Saint Martins College of Art & Design in London, United Kingdom. He also earned a d.MBA in business design in 2021.

Moreover, Jeffrey's research interests have focused on various topics related to HCI, HRI, interactivity, and transdisciplinary experimental creative practice. He obtained his PhD from the National University of Singapore and was a visiting research scholar at Keio University in Japan.

Previously, Jeffrey served as the UX Lead at the National Gallery Singapore, a Peer of the Australia Council for the Arts, a faculty Lecturer at UNSW, Vice President of Transmedia at Villains, and a Partner at Chemistry. He currently serves as an Advisory Board Member at Chemistry, as well as Ngee Ann Polytechnic's School of Design, is a founding member of the World Economic Forum Singapore Chapter, and is an Associate Professor at SIT, focusing on regenerative design and the circular economy.
Head, Design Factory @ Singapore Institute of Technology (DF@SIT)
University of the Arts London: Central Saint Martins

Grant: Tormach PCNC 1100 CNC Mill for Prototyping and Short Run Production of Robot  Components and Metal Objects, MREII Scheme, RG134861, 2014 - $30,000 AUD

Award: Conference on Advances in Computer Entertainment Technology (ACE2010) Creative Showcase Golden Award

Advisory Board Member, Chemistry Team Pte. Ltd.

Advisory Committee Member, School of Design & Environment, Ngee Ann Polytechnic
Partner & Director of Transformation, Chemistry Team Pte. Ltd.
Peer of the Australia Council for the Arts
Exhibition Designer, Office for Metropolitan Architecture

Experimental creative practice is an approach that involves exploring new techniques, materials, or methods to generate innovative and original works. It is characterized by a willingness to take risks, challenge established norms, and push the boundaries of what is considered "traditional" or "conventional" in a particular field.

Design thinking is a human-centered approach to problem-solving and innovation that emphasizes empathy, creativity, and collaboration. It is a methodology that can be applied to a wide range of challenges, from product design to organizational change.

A circular economy is an economic system that aims to eliminate waste and promote sustainability by keeping resources in use for as long as possible. In a circular economy, resources are reused, repaired, refurbished, and recycled, rather than being discarded after a single use.

Regenerative design is an approach to designing and creating built environments, products, services and experiences that seek to create sustainable and resilient systems that actively contribute to the health and well-being of people and the planet. Regenerative design goes beyond just minimizing harm to the environment but aims to actually improve it by creating designs that regenerate natural systems, support biodiversity, and reduce waste and emissions.

Cultural robotics is a field of robotics that explores the interaction between robots and culture. It seeks to design robots that can not only perform tasks and interact with humans but also understand and respect cultural norms, values, and practices.

Experimental creative practice is an approach that involves exploring new techniques, materials, or methods to generate innovative and original works. It is characterized by a willingness to take risks, challenge established norms, and push the boundaries of what is considered "traditional" or "conventional" in a particular field.

Design thinking is a human-centered approach to problem-solving and innovation that emphasizes empathy, creativity, and collaboration. It is a methodology that can be applied to a wide range of challenges, from product design to organizational change.

A circular economy is an economic system that aims to eliminate waste and promote sustainability by keeping resources in use for as long as possible. In a circular economy, resources are reused, repaired, refurbished, and recycled, rather than being discarded after a single use.

Regenerative design is an approach to designing and creating built environments, products, services and experiences that seek to create sustainable and resilient systems that actively contribute to the health and well-being of people and the planet. Regenerative design goes beyond just minimizing harm to the environment but aims to actually improve it by creating designs that regenerate natural systems, support biodiversity, and reduce waste and emissions.

Cultural robotics is a field of robotics that explores the interaction between robots and culture. It seeks to design robots that can not only perform tasks and interact with humans but also understand and respect cultural norms, values, and practices.
